document.title: Explicit examples in ⁢NK1

creator.contact: Department of Mathematics, University of Maryland, College Park MD 20742 U.S.A.

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: For certain rings R, we construct explicit matrices representing nonzero classes in the algebraic K theory group ⁢NK1(R).

document.keywords: algebraic K-theory, Nil group, finite group ring, strong shift equivalence

para.p: The purpose of this note is simply to exhibit explicit matrices representing non-zero classes in the algebraic K-theory group ⁢NK1(R) (and thereby in ⁢Nil0(R)), for some rings R for which ⁢NK1(R) arises as an obstruction in [BoSc2] and [BoSc3]. In [BoSc2], R is the integral group ring of a finite group G; our example is for =G⁢/Z4Z. (Proof of the nontriviality of ⁢NK1(⁢Z[/Z4]) can be found in [Weibel2009] or [SchmiedingNK1FinAbGrps].) In [BoSc3], R is a subring of R; our example is for =R⁢Q[t2,t3,z,z-1] (which has many embeddings into R).It seems to be difficult to locate explicit examples of this sort in the literature. The arguments to follow give some indication as to why that might be the case. The arguments are elementary, and only require carefully tracing through standard arguments and constructions in algebraic K-theory. However, the actual computation becomes lengthy, and leads to fairly large matrix examples.

The computation might be of interest for someone new to K-theory, as an example of the complication buried in certain exact sequence arguments.The author would like to thank Mike Boyle for helpful comments and suggestions.

We will require little setup, all of which can be found in [WeibelBook], or [Rosenberg1994]. Always, R is an associative ring with 1. We consider ⁢K1(R) as the group ⁢/⁢GL(R)El(R), where ⁢GL(R) denotes the stabilized general linear group over R, and ⁢El(R) the stabilized elementary subgroup of ⁢GL(R). There is a map →⁢K1(⁢R[t])⁢K1(R) induced by ↦t0, and the kernel of this map is defined to be ⁢NK1(R). Higman’s trick implies ⁢NK1(R) is the set of elements of ⁢K1(⁢R[t]) which contain a matrix of the form -I⁢tN, with N a nilpotent matrix over R.

The group ⁢Nil0(R) is defined from NilR, the nilpotent category over R. The objects of this category are pairs (P,f), where P is a finitely generated projective R-module and f is a nilpotent endomorphism of P. A morphism →(P,f)(Q,g) is an R module homomorphism :h→PQ such that =⁢hf⁢gh. NilR acquires an exact structure via the forgetful functor Nil→R ProjR given by ↦(P,f)P: a sequence in NilR is exact if its image under this forgetful functor is exact. One may then consider the K-group K0(NilR) of the exact category ⁢NilR (see [WeibelBook, II.7]). The cokernel of the map →⁢K0(⁢ProjR)⁢K0(⁢NilR) given by ↦[P][(P,0)] is denoted ⁢Nil0(R). A well-known isomorphism →⁢NK1(R)⁢Nil0(R) is induced by ↦N-I⁢tN, where N denotes a nilpotent matrix over R (viewed as an endomorphism of Rn, where N is ×nn).
For ≥k1, we recall an important endomorphism of ⁢NK1(R). The Verschiebung map Vk acts on ⁢NK1(R) via =⁢Vk([-1⁢tN])[-1⁢tkN], and acts on ⁢Nil0(R) via

Math.text: V _ k * delimited-[]@(N) = delimited-[]@(Array[[0, 0, cdots, 0, N], [1, 0, 0, cdots, 0], [0, 1, 0, cdots, 0], [vdots, 0, ddots, ddots, vdots], [0, cdots, 0, 1, 0]])

para.p: For ≥k1 there are associated endomorphisms called the Frobenius maps Fk, which act on ⁢NK1(R) via =⁢Fk([-I⁢tN])[-I⁢tNk], and acts on ⁢Nil0(R) via =⁢Fk([N])[Nk]. We will only require the Verschiebung map in the present note.
Consider the ring ⁢Q[t2,t3,z,z-1]. For consistency, we let ⁢NK1(⁢Q[t2,t3,z,z-1]) denote the kernel of the map →↦s0⁢K1(⁢Q[t2,t3,z,z-1,s])⁢K1(⁢Q[t2,t3,z,z-1]). In this section, we show the following.

It follows from [BoSc1, Theorem 5.4] that the nilpotent matrix in (2) of 3.1 is not strong shift equivalent over the ring to the zero matrix (see Section 5). Since this ring may be embedded in R, this provides an example of a matrix over a subring of the reals which is shift equivalent, but not strong shift equivalent, to zero.The remainder of this section is devoted to proving 3.1. An outline for the construction is as follows: we begin with a non-zero class in ⁢K1(/⁢Q[t,s]I) which lies in the kernel of the map induced by ↦s0. Such classes are easy to find. We then proceed by applying a collection of maps to this element, taking care that at each stage of the composition, the element remains non-zero, and ending in ⁢K1(⁢Q[t2,t3,z,z-1,s]). The resulting element still lies in the kernel upon sending ↦s0, so the final element lies in NK1[Q[t2,t3,z,z-1]). The maps which will be applied are shown in the diagram below, starting bottom left and ending top right:
